div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare is £ 9 to Brindisi.
The combined sea and special train fare has been reduced to £ 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Mersailles.

During the Monsoon season the express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Thursday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Saturday.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head:
THE EDUCATION
OF "RAILWAY CHILDREN."
div.p: For some time past the servants of the State Railway Administration who are employed on the service of the permanent way have had a very legitimate grievance against the condi- tions of their employment. The Railway Ad- ministration has very properly insisted that all such employes shall be able to read and write. The percentage of illiterates among them is falling steadily ; e.g. among the platelayers it has dropped from about 80 % to 40 % in ten years, and in the higher native ranks it has almost disappeared.

The men are, almost without exception, married and with families. Those who are employed near the large centres and many of the villages, are, of course, able to send their children to school if they wish, and it to gratifying sign of the times that almost all have realised the importance and value of an education, however unambitious. They have obtained their posts through their knowledge of the three R's, and if their edu- cation has not exactly been advanced it has at least aided them to live a hard-working and useful life.

The men employed on the lines between the stations, and indeed on many of the small stations, have little or no chance of educating their children. Though there are 10,000 kut- tabs in Egypt (if we add to the list of Govern- ment kuttabs, the private kuttabs and those administered by the Wakfs) there are not nearly enough—supposing them to be all per- fectly organised and in the hands of first-rate teachers—for the needs of the country. And as only 4,000, if as many, are regularly inspected by the Government inspectors,and Mr. Dunlop has lamented their shortcomings, it is per- missible to suppose that a large proportion of them serve no very usefal purpose except the teaching by heart of the Koran, which all Moslems support as vigorously as our Anglican clergy and laity support the teaching of the Bible in primary schools, and no doubt for the same good reasons.

But if a large number of children who frequent the kuttabs are very imperfectly taught, what of the enormous numbers who are not taught at all ? Among these last none, we think, deserve assistance more than the children of the railway employes whom we have mentioned, and we are glad to be able to state that, thanks to the energy of Mr.Cotterill, something is being done for the children of 1,400 or 1,500 railway men who cannot avail themselves of other kuttabs, and are in consequence condemned to illiteracy as long as their fathers remain at out-of-the- way posts.

Owing to Mr. Cotterill's exertions some 95 kut- tabs have already been founded for their benefit, and, we may add, for the benefit of children who, live in the same neighbourhood and suffer the same disadvantages. We need not say that this number will shortly be augmented, for much remains to be done ; at least 1,200 em- ployes are in reach of no school where their children can be taught, and the exigencies of the time-table, or the fact that they are posted between stations, prevent them from making use of the free passes granted to scholars. There cannot be any doubt that the men will support the kuttabs and send their children to them as fast as they are formed. They have not to pay a high price for their children's instruction—P.T. 2 a month for one child and P.T. 3 for all the children of a family—but even these small sums count with men who, besides their wives and small children, often maintain their parents and divorced or widowed sisters, and it is very gratifying to note that scarcely any have grudged the payment. We hope to have more to say about this interesting subject in the near future.

div.head:
THE WAR.
SAUHALIEN SURRENDERS.
VANGUARDS OF RIVAL ARMIES IN CONTACT.

div.p: 3,270 Russians have surrendered in Sagha- lien Island. (Havas.)
The bulk of the Saghalien garrison, compris- ing the governor, 70 officers, and 3,200 men, surrendered on the 31st July. (Reuter.)

The Russians on the south bank of the Tumen are completely cut off by the floods which have followed the heavy rains. Mean- while several strong Japanese columns are reported to be advancing through northern Korea, threatening their positions. The van- guards of the two armies are already in contact. (Reuter.)

div.head:
PEACE CONFERENCE.
SUCCESS REGARDED AS DOUBTFUL.

div.p: The Peace Conference will meet on the 8th inst. (Reuter.)
The success of the peace negotiations is regarded here as doubtful, and the indignation against the arrogant attitude of Russia is growing. (Reuter.)

div.head: WHAT THE WAR HAS COST JAPAN.

div.p: M. Sato states that the war has cost Japan up to the present time £100,000,000, but that it Is usual to ask an indemnity exceeding the sum actually expended. (Reuter.)

div.head:
THE PASSPORT CASE.
ACCUSED FINED £100 EACH.

div.p: The journalist Mr. Brailsford and the actor McCullogh, mentioned on the 23rd May, have been fined £100 each. (Reuter.)

div.head:
KING EDWARD AND THE KAISER.
APPROACHING MEETING.

div.p: King Edward will have a meeting with Em- peror William on his way to Marienbad. (H.)
M. Jaluzot has lost 15 millions (francs) in speculating for the rise in sugar. Several of the brokers on the Bourse have had to liquidate. (Havas).

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alexan dria, Madame Sidky, and party paid a visit last Friday to Mr. and Mrs. Chitaway at Yateley, Hants. After luncheon the party drove through the grounds of Wellington College and on to Strathfieldsaye.
Mr. R. Carton, de Wiart Bey is among the passengers leaving for Europe to-day by the Austrian Lloyd steamer.
A telegram from Royat announces the death of M. Sotiri Bouphides, vice-president of the Mansourah Mixed Tribunal.

div.head: Agricultural Exhibition,—
div.p: Mr. Machel has invited the moudirs of Upper Egypt to take the necessary steps in aid of the Agricultural Exhibition that will be held at Fayoum in September.

Suez Canal.—14 vessels passed through the Canal on the 2nd inst., of which 9 were British, 1 Dutch, 1 Austrian, 1 Italian, 1 Norwegian, 1 Turkish. The day's receipts were fra. 369,921.46, making the total for the first two days in the month fra. 690,588 79.

div.head: Attempted Suicide.—
div.p: A man employed in one of the leading stores in Tantah attempted to commit suicide on Thursday by cutting his throat. Although his condition is very serious, hopes are entertained of his recovery. His action is attributed to monetary difficulties.

div.head: Sir Wm. Willcocks and the Punjab.—
div.p: A telegram from Lahore states that Sir William Willcocks is making inquiries as to the pos- sibility of obtaining a grant of about fifty thousand acres of State land in the Punjab for agricultural development by a syndicate or company.

div.head: Coal Imports.—
div.p: From the 1st January to the 3rd August, 555,285 tons of coal were imported into Egypt. Wales sent 311,454, Newcastle 122,745, Scotland 70,080, York- shire 30,988, and other places 19,968 tons. During the same period of last year 564,780 tons were received.

div.head: The Nadouri Murder.—
div.p: It appears there is no foundation for the report that the secret police had discovered the identity of the murderer of Nadouri Pasha. They are. on the contrary, still hunting for the clue to a mystery, which we cannot help thinking would be better left unsolved.

div.head: An Abyssinian Mission.—
div.p: A telegram from Djibouti to the "Temps" states that Mechacha, an important personage of the Court of the Emperor Menelik, left on the 24th ulto. for Jerusalem, whence he will proceed to Constan- tinople, Vienna, Berlin, and Paris, and perhaps to London. Some political importance is attach- ed to this mission.

div.head: New Cairo Hotel. —
div.p: A group of Swiss capitalists has been authorised to build a hotel on the Suares and Cattaoui lands at Kasr- el-Nil. It is said that the new building will be constructed after the plans of the Cecil Hotel in London, with a large terrace looking over the river. Building operations will be commenced next month.

The Austrian Lloyd S.S. Company in- form us that, in order to meet the many demands for passages from Trieste to Alexandria, they have decided to run a few extra steamers between the regular sailings. The first of these extra departures will take place on the 8th October, arriving at Alexandria on the 12th at daylight, to sail again for Trieste on the 15th October at 3 p.m.

div.head: Lack of Employes.—
div.p: The recent opening of new banks has produced a very great demand for employes ; and the question arises as to whether there will be sufficient to fill the vacancies. It is certain that in spite of this abnormal demand those applicants who have the best education and knowledge of languages will have the preference ; and those who frequent the Berlitz Schools will find a just recompense for their efforts in this direction by a rapid and practical method. [Advt.]

div.head: Alhambra. Theatre.—
div.p: The Della Guardia Italian dramatic company arrived yesterday by the Florio-Rubattino steamer and, as already announced, opens at the Alhambra this evening with Sardou's famous comedy Fedora The title role will be taken by of Signa. G. Della Guardis, and the other parts are also in seemingly good hands. We look forward to an excellent performance this evening. To-morrow afternoon a matinee performance will be given, and in the evening Le Maitre des Forg s ("The Ironmaster") will be produced. The latest success of the French stage, L'Autre Danger, is to be staged on Monday.

div.head:
FIRE ON NILE FERRY.
EXCITING INCIDENT AT FARASKOUR.
div.p: We publish the following extracts from a letter describing the adventures of one of the cotton worm inspectors, who, we hope, will allow us to compliment him on the courage and coolness he evidently showed under the most trying circumstances. We withhold the writer's name for the present, as we have not received his permission to publish it:—

"I arrived safely on Monday evening, but not without some exciting experiences. It is really wonder that I am alive to tell the tale, for 10 minutes I was facing death by two means, burning and drowning; and this is how it happened. You must know that to get to Faraskour from the station it is necessary to cross the Nile by ferry. The train arrives at the station at 9.15 and as it happened on Monday night there was only one ferry boat, and quite 20 people came in it, besides bring- ing heaps of baggage and luggage of all sorts. The boat was crammed and there was not room to move one's legs. I was sitting on a seat by the mast. There were two women in the boat and one of these had a young child. There was a candle burning in a lamp in the middle of the boat about two feet from me on the floor. As we were just in the middle of the river I heard a crash, and on looking round found that a man who was carrying a very large bottle, had dropped it and the contents, which looked like wine to me in the dark, flowed all over the bottom of the boat. The bottle must have held nearly a gallon. I had just said to the boatman, "Be careful you don't cut your feet," when a huge flame shot up from the bottom of the boat almost to the top of the mast. The bottle contained spirits of wine, and when this reached the candle it of course ignited. There was an awful scramble in the crowded boat for a moment and the yells and screams of the frightened people were terrible. I managed to scramble to my feet and at once shouted to the boy who was steering to make straight for the bank. I then set myself to keep the poor wretches from throwing themselves into the river, and from capsizing the boat by making them crowd together at both ends of the boat. I seized the first thing that I could put my hands upon, and it happened to be a broom. With this I fought the flames. There were two poor men whose clothes were burning on them from head to foot, and I thought they would certainly be burnt to death. I brushed the flames downwards and succeeded in extinguish- ing their burning clothes,and they were drawn along out of further danger for the time, but they were both very badly burnt. I then started to try and put out the flames on the floor of the boat, and succeeded in brushing all the spirit between the floor of the boat and the bottom, where it continued to burn fiercely. We then got to the bank. I made the two women land first, and then all the men except the two who were burnt, and then we pushed off again, the flames still burning under us till we reached the landing place. I saw we could do that without much further danger. We got there all right I had sent a man for the doctor when the first lot landed, and had called to Bisheer to bring a lantern, for it was as dark as pitch. Just as we got to the landing place the flames had burnt them- selves out, and we lifted the two poor men ashore in great agony. I sent off at once for olive oil and cotton wool and when it came, dressed their burns and sent them home. But the crowd was immense, and the wailing of the women, the crying of the children, and the cries of agony from the men were enough to turn one's brain. I came up to my tent and drank nearly half a bottle of port, and then went off to their houses to see how they were. They are getting along all right, as the burns were only superficial, but still very large and painful. It was an experience I don't want again in a hurry. I am sure had I not been there they would all have been drowned or burnt to death, as everyone had lost his head. I have not quite got over it yet."

div.head: SEEDS IN EGYPTIAN TOMBS.
div.p: Mrs. A.B. MacGregor writes to the "Morn- ing Post" :-Havirg read the paragraph, under the heading of "Discovery and Invention" in your issue of Jully 22 with regard to the seed found in the tombs of Egyptian mummies, think the following account of "Mummy Corn," by my husband, the late Mr. John MacGregor may interest your readers. "Mummy Corn." On June 9,1871, a wooden sarcophagus brought from the Khedive of Egypt by the Duke of Sutherland, was opened at Stafford House by Dr. Birch, of the British Museum, and Mr. John MacGregor. The lid of the mummy case seemed to have been unopened before, as the clay luting was in the joint nearly all round. From the hieroglyphics outside Dr. Birch pro- nounoed the mummy to be that of a priest sacred to Osiris, and about two thousand six hundred years old, and he predicted there would be found inside several articles, a blue glass net, images, &c., which were found within. Among the loose debris inside the case were four grains of corn ;two of these Mr. Mac- Gregor planted a few days afterwards in small flower-pot filled with sifted mould froi the Temple Gardens, the other two grains were sent to Mr. Sowerby, at the Royal Botanic Society, Regent's Park; the pot from the Temple was also sent to Mr. Sowerby in August with one of the grains grown up about eight inches high. This was returned in December 1871, as a stalk four feet long with twelve grains of oats growing on it; the other two grains grew up into several stalks, but with- out fruit."

div.head: THE YEMEN RISING.
TROOPS THROUGH THE CANAL.
div.p: The transport Assyr has passed through the canal en route for Hodeida with 800 soldiers on board, and six other Turkish transports are expected to enter the canal in the next few days. Litters from Hodeida report suc- cesses on the part of Shakir Pasha and Faizi Pasha, but it seems that the Turks have not yet reached Menakha, and that some time must elapse before they can advance in force against the passes of the coast range.

div.head: HEDJAZ RAILWAY.
div.p: Field Marshal Hakki Pasha, A. D. C. to the Sultan, Nazim Pasha, Governor of Syria, Field Marshal Raif Pasha, Hamdi Bey, and several of the German officials employed upon the Hedjaz Railway, recently paid a visit to Ma'au and are reported to be highly pleased with the progress and general condition of the railway, which has now reached a point 28 kilometres south of Ma'an.

div.head: STEAMER ASHORE IN THE CANAL.
div.p: Suez, Friday.

The British India steamer Matiana, bound to Calcutta, grounded in the Canal the other side of Ismailia this forenoon, and is blocking the traffic. The tug "Titan" is leaving Suez this afternoon to render assistance to the stranded steamer.

div.head: LIGHT KEEPER'S SUICIDE.
div.p: Suez, Friday.

Last Wednesday afternoon the lighthouse keeper of the Newport Rook, Mr. F. L. Gower, committed suicide at the Hotel Bel Air here by shooting himself with a revolver through the mouth. The bullet pierced the skull and death was instantaneous. The motive, if any, for the act is unknown, but it is attributed to tem- porary insanity. Mr. Gower was recently ap- pointed to Suakin, and had intended sailing by the S.S. Missir on the afternoon of his death, to take up his new post.

div.head: PHARMACY REGULATIONS.
div.p: The instructions distributed by the Sanitary Department to the proprietors of pharmacies are, as far as we can judge, well and clearly drawn up. All proprietors are now obliged to catalogue their stock of drugs alphabetically, while poisons, arranged in alphabetical order, must be placed in special compartments and grouped. Mineral waters must be kept under- ground if possible, to avoid the rays of the sun. The keys of all medicine chests, drawers, etc., containing poison must be kept in the sole charge of a pharmacist who is in possession of a diploma. All orders and prescriptions must be entered daily in a special register, and the shop assistants may not hand over to customers any medicine or drug containing poison. Prescrip- tion must be returned to their bearers, but in cases where they contain a medical error, the pharmacist is to keep the document as a 'piece justificative' and give a copy to the person for whom it has been drawn up. Proprietors are held responsible for the purity of all drugs in medicines that leave their pharmacies.

div.head: EXPORT OF GUM ARABIC.
div.p: During the month of June, 806.985 kilos of gum arabic, valued at L.E. 19,342, was ex- ported from Egypt. In the same month of 1904 the exports were 861,458 kilos, of the value of L.E. 19,380; a decrease in 1905 of 54,473 kilos, value LE. 38.

From the 1st January to the 30th June, 1905, the exports to England and her Medi- terranean possessions were 564,330 kilos, value L.E. 13,100 ; Germany 1,172,657 kilos, value L.E. 27,409 ; Austria-Hungary, 312,122 kilos, value LE. 7,191;France and Algeria, 1,073,501 kilos, value LE. 24,806 ; Italy, 193,103 kilos, value, L.E. 4,462; Turkey, 3,822 kilos, value LE. 87 ; America, 619,366 kilos, value LE. 12.017 ; and to other countries 704,496 kilos, value LE. 16,414, a decrease in 1905 of 392,086 kilos, value L.E. 5,546.

div.head: THE COMPTOIR NATIONAL.
div.p: The Comptoir National d'Escompte de Paris opens its new agency at Alexandria on the 7th inst. For the present, the offices of the Comptoir National are installed on the first floor of the Antoniades Building, Cherif Pasha- street They will be transferred to the ground floor as soon as the necessary changes in the building, which are in course of completion, have been carried through.

The Comptoir National's capital amounts to frs. 150,000,000, all paid up. It has 40 branches in Paris, 111 in France, and many others in Loudon, Manchester, and Liverpool, in Morocco and Tunis, the East Indies, 3 Australia and Madagascar. Its excellent or- ganisation enables it to meet the financial and commercial needs of Alexandria under the best possible conditions.
The manager of the agency is Mr. Pierre Llewellyn. Messrs' G. J. Buissiez and Henry Pougin are sub-managers. Mr. Edouard Savig- non has full powers in all share and bourse transactions. 28308-8-9

div.head: ENGLAND, GERMANY AND TURKEY IN THE NEAR EAST.
div.p: BY WILHELM MEISTER.
(Translated).
(Continued from July 28).

An offensive movement of the nature I have described would be attended by difficulties that would prevent its execution from being a mere matter of a week, or a month. Several months' preparation would be required, and during this interval the hypothetical invader would not have failed to disembark strong contin- gents to discipline and train the volunteers of the Lebanon and to undertake the defence of the eastern glacis of the mountain rampart. Even admitting the all but impossible possibi- lity that the Turks, with all their want of organisation, could capture the barrier, their success would cost them half their effectives, and a further advance down the western glacis would soon be checked by the fleet's guns.

Under these circumstances it is hardly probable that their commanders would risk the adventure, and one may fairly assert that they would regard an immobile and defensive attitude screened by the Anti-Lebanon as the only practicable and safe alternative. There they would stay waiting for reinforcements or the disbandment of their army. And reinforce- ments would not reach them. The sea routes would be closed, the precipitous Tarns would impede the advance of an Anatolian army, and it is hard to see from what quarter fresh troops would come. The defensive force, immobile, harassed, and disorganised, would break up, and Syria of her own accord would unfasten the bonds that unite her to the Turkish Empire.
I now pass to the second hostile element, the German Empire.

In my first study of the question I establish- ed that Germany's only method and plan of striking England on land presupposes the employment of the reorganised Turkish army. It is obvious enough that if the Ottoman armies in Syria, the hue of operations against England, are not ready to respond to the pro- posal of Germany, the plan of England's rival is foredoomed, and being a sagacious power, Germany will not dream of attempting its execution. It is essential to remember that the Turkish army will never become that wedge of proved steel, on which Germany counts, till the completion of the system of strategic rail- ways enables its leaders to make the reform general, and bring the Syrian Corps into line with the rest. Failing this Von der Goltz's great ideas must remain unfruitful and 'Car- thage' can rest in peace, for it is not on the waves that Germany will measure herself against her great rival and defy Leviathan on his own element.
Syria may therefore be amputated without any fear from this quarter, and though Ger- many may threaten and chide she will not prevent the operation.

The third hostile element, as formidable but yesterday as the giant Polyphemas, has been beaten to the ground and lies in the convul- sions of a revolution. Russia, the victim of the England of the East, exhausted and all but expiring, cannot lift a little finger to check the conquest of a province where yesterday her feverish activity was laying landmarks for future conquest.

France and Italy remain. Immemorial tradi- tion and the memory of former interventions and glorious struggles on behalf of the Christians of the East have made both, and especially France, the protectors of the Syrian Coast. But both these Powers, strangely enough, appear to be to some extent falling back in face of the rights which England has acquired in the Levant by virtue of her occupation of Egypt and her position in India and Arabia, and are turning for their expansion to other parts of the Medi- terranean, Italy to Tripoli in Barbary (another province that seems ready for amputation), and France to Morocco, where Germany has lately threatened to dislodge her, though in reality the great central Power would infinitely prefer to dislodge its insular rival (and all others) from the Levant.

It certainly seems that France and Italy have finally given up their dreams of expan- sion in Syria and the Holy Land in return for advantages that guarantee their integrity in Europe and the development of their African possessions. Well-informed students of interna- tional politics are fully aware that both France and Italy would welcome either of the solu- tions of the Syrian question that we have suggested and if necessary would aid in their realisation. They have ever played a noble and chivalrous part on behalf of the oppressed nationalities of the Near East, for whom they have sacrificed money and blood, and whose deliverance from their thraldom would crown with success the secular aspirations of the Latin race.
(To be concluded).

div.head: EMPIRE COTTON.
PROGRESS TO DATE.
div.p: The marvellous progress which has been made during the past three years in the deve- lopment of the cotton-growing industry within the confines of the Empire clearly indicates that the day is not far distant when the British spinner will not be at the mercy of the United States for his supplies of the raw material. This movement to develop new sources of supply was not initiated'a moment too soon. Apart from the obvious absurdity which de- pendence upon a foreign country for such a commodity entails, when there are thousands of miles of British territory capable of pro- ducing it in quantities and quality equal to all home requirements, there was a much more serious aspect of the question developing apace. The United States has not only nearly reached the economic limit in production of the new material, but that country's domestic requirements have been of late years increas- ing in an adverse ratio to the free ship- ment abroad of the commodity. In other words, the United States spinners, in a com- paratively brief period of time, provided recognised agricultural and economic laws are not outraged in their interests, will require to look outside their own country for addi- tional supplies of raw cotton. Assuming that the rest of the world depended upon India and Egypt—which, had the new cotton-grow- ing districts not been developed, they would unquestionably have done — ruin stared the spinning industries of Europe in the face, and consumers everywhere would not only have depended upon America for such supplies of raw material as she chose to release, but for the manufactured products as well.

The development, then, of cotton-growing within the British Empire is a matter of im- portance, not only to the Lancashire spinner, but consumers of all classes throughout the world. Instead of being dependent as they practically are at present—for Great Britain takes practically half of the present Indian crop and a very heavy percentage of the Egyptian output, the balance of the former scarcely meeting local requirements and the balance of the latter being so widely distri- buted that it can scarcely be regarded in any one instance as a certain source of supply— upon the United States crop, grown in what is, after all, a comparatively limited area and subject to almost similar weather conditions, the surplus outputs of British Colonies and dependencies all over the world will in a few years be available for the consumers of raw material. It is impossible to imagine such a state of affairs as the universal failure of the British crop, considering that we shall be able to draw upon India, Egypt, South Africa, West Africa, East Africa, the West Indies, British North Borneo, Australia and the Malay States, to say nothing of other widely distributed centres, for our supplies.

The cotton thus produced is not a make- shift, and for proof of this assertion one has merely to stroll round the excellent little exhibition of British-grown cotton which has been got together at the Imperial Institute, and is open daily at South Kensington. The exhibition is proof—if such were needed—of the energy which the British Cotton Growing Association has displayed in fulfilling the task it set itself to perform three years ago. As the result of its first year's work cotton to the value of £100,000 was grown in British territories where it had not been produced commercially within the memory of man, and this year the value of the output should exceed a quarter of a million sterling. This sum, large though it be, is admittedly a mere trifle when placed side by side with the value of our total imports of raw cotton ; but it must be remembered that it represents the product of entirely new areas brought under cultivation on scientific lines. The outlay to achieve this result, too, has been compara- tively heavy, but had it been a hundred times as large the results can be said to perfectly justify the expenditure.

Omitting reference in detail to India and Egypt—where, however, the areas under cul- tivation are increasing each year—it is interest- ing to note the very material progress which has been made in Colonies where the growing of cotton has been initiated by the association. Few people are probably aware of the fact that the United States received its first consign- ment of cotton-seed a hundred and seventy years ago from the West Indies, via the Chelsea Physic Gardens. Yet such is the case, and, what is more, these islands during the first year of the last century shipped to Europe no less than ten million pounds of the raw material. In 1836 the exports had fallen to eight million pounds, and in 1901 they had declined to the infinitesimal total of 280,000 pounds. The ap- parent collapse of what was, undoubtedly, a profitable industry was due to the introduction of sugar-growing in the islands. With a lack of foresight many of their descendants have had good cause to regret, the planters rushed at the new industry to the detriment of the old, and left the supplying of the raw cotton market to the Americans. They have, however, taken up cotton-growing again with such vigour that in two yews they doubled the output of 1901, and a the present rate of progression the crops from the Antilles should, in a brief period of time, exceed the highly respectable total of 1801. At the present moment St Vincent pro- duces probably the finest Sea Island cotton in the world, while the Barbadoes, Trinidad, St Kitts, and Antigua are not far behind that colony in the quality of their products. The 1905 crop is estimated at 5,000 360-lb bales, valued at something like £100,000.

The Sudan, too, will shortly be a factor to be reckoned, with in the production of raw cotton. When, the fact is recalled that the total exports in 1902 amounted to only four cwts, the progress which has been made by Egypt's dependency will be understood and appreciated by the statement that in 1904 8,000 acres were under cultivation with com- mercial cotton, the bulk of which was available for export. West Africa is another more than promising cotton-growing centre. Until the Cotton-Growing Association and the Govern- ment took matters in hand, the cotton grown by the natives was of little or no commercial value. Experiments with good seed, under the direction of competent instructors, soon show- ed the natives that a new industry, with which they already had an elementary acquaintance, could be created, and they have worked at it to some purpose. At any rate, raw cotton to the value of £7,310 was shipped in 1903, and the output, now that large areasure going into cultivation, is bound to increase in the near future. In Natal and in the Transvaal, in Rhodesia and Swaziland, extensive experi- mental plantations are in existence, and from some of these centres good commercial cotton has already been obtained. In East Africa and British Central Africa the growing of the Egyptian variety of cotton and the improve- ment of native varieties has been taken in hand. Indeed; in no British possession in the Dark Continent has the production of cotton been shown to be impossible ; and when, in some of the colonies, questions of transport and labour have been solved, a steady output from all of them can with confidence be anti- cipated.

In Asia, outside India, some very excellent samples—they are nothing more, however— from the Straits Settlements and the Malay States are shown at the Imperial Institute ; but the cultivation of the plant suffers from an uncertain climate, attacks of parasites and lack of labour, so that the difficulties in the way of successful production are bound to retard private individuals embarking in the industry, especially when other money-making enterprises are at their hand. North Borneo, however, promises to be an important addition to British Empire cotton areas. The climate is suitable, and the supply of necessary labour is ample. Cotton grows wild in North Borneo, as, indeed, it does in nearly all the centres enumerated above—and efforts are being made to improve the native variety, as well as in- troduce cultivated cotton from India and other recognised producing areas. In Australia the labour problem retards not only the growing of cotton commercially in Queensland—where at one time it was somewhat extensively cultivated for export—but also the carrying out of experiments in other parts of the con- tinent. In the Fiji Islands a parallel in many ways to the West Indies can be found. These islands at one time grew cotton extensively, the shipments in 1870 being valued at £93,000, but by 1902 the exports had entirely ceased. Causes of a local character led to the collapse of this industry, but efforts are now being made to revive it, and as the principal diffi- culty in the way of successful cultivation has been removed there is no reason why the Fiji Islands should not in a few years' time, again figure among the list of shippers of raw cotton to Great Britain.

The Imperial Institute Exhibition professes to show the cotton industry from the growing plant to the manufactured product. This it does do in a fashion which is easily under- standed of the people. In an hour's time a man of average intelligence can learn more of one of our most important industries by visiting the Institute's little show than he would probably learn from a year's solid reading of books dealing with the subject. Even the wisest and youngest of us can learn some- thing from a glance round these carefullyarranged exhibits.

div.head: LONDON COMMERCIAL REPORT.
div.p: IVORY.—The quarterly ivory sales com- menced 25th inst. and concluded 27th inst. ; they comprised 61 tons (against 54 tons same time last year), viz: 20 1/2 tons Zanzibar, Bombay, Mozambique and Siam, 6 tons Abys- sinian, 21 tons Egyptian (17 1/4 tons Alexandrian, tons Malta description), tons West Coast African, 1/2 ton Lisbon and 6 3/4 tons land carriage, also 1 3/4 tons sea horse teeth, a few walrus' tusks, and 14 1/2 tons waste ivory - total 77 1/4 tons.
Of the above quantities 8 tons were indi- rect import or ex sale lots, viz. 6 3/4 tons land carriage and 1 1/4 tons sea horse teeth.
There was a good general demand, and competition was fairly active throughout.

The quantity offered was larger than at recent sales, more particularly of Zanzibar and Egyptian, and contained a large propor- tion of soft ivory. Prices were a little irre- gular, and in some instances rather in buyers' favor.
The five tons Abyssinian ivory, which ar- rived previous to the April sales,and remained unclaimed in the docks for some time, has now found an owner in the Emperor Menelik of Abyssinia.
Gum Arabic. — 180 bales withdrawn or bought in, including Sudan mixed hard and soft sorts part woody and dusty at 30 s.
Gum Kino.— 2 cases sold at 1s.
Gum Benjamin. - Of 50 cases 2 sold, good Sumatra 2nds at 7l.
Gum Myrrh. —Of 33 cases 28 sold at 45s ; 1 lot at 49s.
Gum Elemi.—5 cases sold, good white well incented at 25s, yellowish part hard at 21s; 1 lot at 10s.
Gum Olibanum—9 cases bought in.

div.head: INSULTING THE SULTAN.
div.p: Among the animals performing at the Royal Italian Circus, says the Evening Standard, on behalf of the Fresh Air Fund, is Fasolin, the acrobatic and trapeze monkey. Although Fasolin can rival the cleverest human performers on the trapeze, he has hot yet learned to read. If his education had been attended to in-this respect he would have been greatly interested in the news of the attempt on the life of the Sultan of Turkey by bomb-throwing miscreants. Fasolin, however, alone amongst monkeys, has had the dubious honor of throwing glass- lustres at the Sultan.

He committed this outrage some years ago at a command performance at Yildiz Kiosk. A trapeze was put up on the ceiling of a grand saloon, which was illuminated by great glass chandeliers. Something, frightened the monkey, which, instead of swinging to the trapeze, sprang on one of the chandeliers,and to Signor Volpi's consternation proceeded to tear off the lustres and pelt the Sublime Porte with them.

Everyone trembled for the audacious mon- key's fate. A sack and the Bosphorus were thought to be his deserts, but the Sultan was greatly amused, and presented his owner with a gold repeater, £500 in English money and the Order of the Medjidie. Fasolin is now 16 years old, and the cleverest mon- key at the Circus. Any little people, how- ever, who patronise the F.A.F performance need have no fear that Fasolin will mis- conduct himself as he did years ago At Yildiz Kiosk. He has grown wiser, as well as older, and he is now the gentlest monkey Signor Volpi possesses.

div.head: MISUNDERSTOOD.
div.p: Russia persists in the statement that her army in Manchuria is still anxious and willing to fight. Impartial observers returned from the front tell us that officers and privates alike are panting for peace, but that the authorities have for long been terrified at the idea of leading home an army discontented by being led so often into defeat. But this is not the first time there has been misunderstanding to the attitude of Russian troops. An English traveller met a body of Russian peasants, handcuffed and chained together, and being driven like cattle along the road by soldiers. "Dear me !" said he to the officer in charge ; "who are these prisoners ?" "Prisoners ?" re-echoed the officer. "These are not prisoners. They are volunteers —hastening to the front !"

div.head: LORD CROMER.
HIS LIFE AND WORK
div.p: (Harold Spender in the "Leisure Hour").

"If you want to see all the sights of Cairo," the English resident will tell you, as soon as you reach the Nile from Port Said, "you must go to the Zoological Gardens on Sunday after- noon and see Lord Cromer." The instruction sounds puzzling, and perhaps a little disre- spectful to British authority. But if you take the advice, what then ? After you have seen the lions feed, admired the chimpanzee, and talked to the cockatoos, you will go and drink tea at the Pelican Island. Then, if you keep your eyes open, you will soon see the great sight.

A little family party—father, wife, nurse and child—come strolling along. There is no state—no escort, no footmen, no Consular "Ca- vasses" sparkling in gold and white. It is just a little middle-class party out for their Sunday afternoon—enjoying the holiday and the sun- shine, gazing at the strange animals — im- mensely concerned and interested in the baby. "Monsieur, Madame, and Bebe"—you see the same group wandering along under the trees in the Champs-Elysees, or under the lime-trees in any little German town. The man is grey- haired, but still keen-eyed, strongly built, and bronzed of face. He seems more anxious about the baby than either the mother or the nurse.

I open with this picture from his life at Cairo because it conveys in the best possible manner the secret of Lord Cromer's rule in Egypt. The secret lies in its simplicity. You are often told by the followers of other schools that the only way to govern the East is by display. Lord Cromer knows the East quite as well as any man ; but he has chosen the way of simplicity.

Mark the result. "The meek shall inherit the earth"—Lord Cromer's simplicity has suc- ceeded where display would probably have utterly failed. Twenty years ago, when he entered upon his present task, Lord Cromer was surrounded with enemies. He might have fought them with display. He has chosen a better and a more successful plan.

The house in which Lord Cromer lives is no palace, but just the old British Consulate. It stands in the European residential quarter, not far from the Nile, and all the Arab drivers of the smart little two-horse victorias which brighten the European quarter know it, if they know it at all, as "Lord Cromer's."

It is an old-fashioned mid-Victorian mansion with a couple of wings. There is a pleasant, well-lighted drawing-room ; but the centre from which Egypt is governed is the high, rather sombre, chamber which Lord Cromer uses as his official study.

There, every morning, he receives all the English official "Advisers" who constitute his real Cabinet. There is an Egyptian Cabinet, of course, just as there is a Khedive ; but they all have to obey the instructions of their English "Advisors." And all those instruc- tions are supervised by Lord Cromer. It is no exaggeration therefore, to say that Egypt is governed from this study.

To do all this work at his age, Lord Cromer has to live the simplest possible life. Since his severe illness a few years ago, he never dines out. His young wife, a sister of the Marquis of Bath and a Thynne, dines out for him and busily looks after the whole social side of his life. He himself goes to bed early and rises early.
The whole morning he devotes to seeing the "Advisers." In the afternoon he drives out with his wife and child. After six o'olock he is accessible again to any person with a claim to see him.
He is, in fact, the hardest-worked man in Egypt. He can only keep the work going by becoming the servant — almost the slave— of duty.
"Who is that very quiet young man ?" a lady is said to have asked Sir Henry Storks in the sixties in Malta. "He seems to have nothing to say for himself."
"That is young Baring."
Even in those days Lord Cromer never wasted words.
At that time he was aide de camp to Sir Henry Storks as the Governor of Malta, and went with Sir Henry on his journey to Jamaica as a member of the Eyre Commission.
This was towards the end of his first career —that of a soldier.

Born at Cromer Hall in Norfolk on Feb- ruary 26th, 1841, the son of Henry Baring, he entered Woolwich when still a boy and became a Lieutenant of Artillery in 1858. He worked hard at the military calling, wrote military essays, became a Captain in 1868, and passed through the Staff College.

Perhaps he might have stuck to the military profession and gained renown as a General if he had not been appointed as aide de camp to Sir Henry Storks when High Commissioner of the Ionian Islands in 1860. He followed Sir Henry to Malta and thence to Jamaica. In 1872-6 he went to India as private secretary to his cousin, Lord Northbrook, the "Viceroy ; and at the end of that period he retired defi- nitely from the Army as Major, and passed from the sphere of arms to that of diplomacy.

In 1879 he became a Commissioner of the Egyptian Debt, and afterwards one of the Controller-Generals under the dual control. In 1880 he went back to India as the Financial Member of the Council of India in succession to Sir John Strachey, and remained there three years. He returned to England in 1883, was made a K.C.S.I., and appointed to succeed Sir Edward Malet as Consul-General and Minister Plenipotentiary in Egypt.
The actual beginning of his real power in Egypt dates from September 4th of that year—1883.

This brief sketch of Lord Cromer's life will show that he went to Egypt with a very full training both in military and dip- lomatic affairs—with a valuable experience of Anglo-Indian administration - and with a thorough knowledge of Egypt itself. All this must have done a great deal to prepare him for his great success.

Lord Cromer—then Sir Evelyn Baring— arrived in Egypt at a most critical and difficult moment. A few weeks after his ar- rival (on November 5th) General Hicks' army of 10,000 Egyptian soldiers was massacred in the Sudan. At the beginning of the new year (1884) the British Government began to put forward the momentous proposal that General Charles Gordon, then generally known as "Chinese Gordon," should be sent out to relieve the situation in the Sudan. Sir Evelyn Baring at first strongly opposed this suggestion, but ultimately agreed, on the strict understanding that General Gordon's mission should be limited to the task of evacuating the Sudan as quickly as possible.*

For the whole of the next year Sir Evelyn Baring was absorbed in this distracting episode of General Gordon's mission and the siege of Khartoum. His prime duty was to act as the channel between the Cabinet in London and General Gordon in the Sudan. It was no easy task. At one end of the cable was a hero—"a hero of heroes," as Mr. Gladstone himself called him—but a hero who was not easy to govern.

The contrast of character sharp and complete. On the one side a man of precise and practical vision : on the other an idealist. Those strange jottings of lonely peril, General Gordon's Journals, show us the impatience which Sir Evelyn Baring's caution aroused in General Gordon. It was the impatience of a tired and over-wrought man. When we con- sider the conditions of that awful, lonely, siege we cannot wonder ; but we must remem- ber that it was Baring's duty to carry out the policy of the Government.

In February and March, 1884, General Gordon sent to Baring eleven telegrams in as many days, making varied suggestions for a way out of their difficulties. On March 2nd Sir Evelyn Baring replied as follows :-

"I have received your eleven telegrams of the last four days on matters of general policy. I am most anxious to help and support you in every way, but find it very difficult to understand exactly what you want. I think your best plan will be to reconsider the whole question carefully, and then state to me in one telegram what it is you recommend."
There is no document which sums up better the difference between the two men—Genera Gordon's heroic, restless optimism, and Baring's prosaic but practical common-sense.
We are none of us always right in our prophecies, and General Gordon would have claimed no special privilege. There is one passage in his Journals, written in 1884, which
comes back to one's mind with curious rebound when one thinks of Lord Cromer to-day:—

"We seldom realise our position. In ten or twelve years' time Baring, Lord Wolseley, myself, Evelyn Wood, etc., will have no teeth and will be deaf; some of us will be quite passe; no one will come and court us; new Barings, new Lord Wolseleys will have arisen, who will call us 'bloaks' and 'twaddlers."
Not ten, nor twelve, but more than twenty years have passed, yet Lord Cromer is still the central, and one of the most youthful figures in Egypt.

After the fall of Khartoum Sir Evelyn Baring resumed that policy of abandoning, the Sudan which he had always advocated in the then condition of Egyptian finance. He had "helped and supported" General Gordon in every way, even to the extent of backing him up in his proposal to set Zobeir, the old slave- raider, in command of the Sudan. He had advised the sending of the relief expedition and given every help to Lord Wolseley, though he had vetoed Gordon's proposal that he should retire to the Equator. On the whole, the practical man had stood loyally by the dreamer in his extremity. But now that Gor- don was dead, he strongly recommended the abandonment of the expedition to Khartoum.

The Liberal Cabinet adopted his advice in April, 1885, and the Government of Lord Salisbury carried on the policy of Mr. Gladstone until 1896, when at last the condition of Egypt justified Lord Kitchener's re-conquest. Thus Lord Cromer was given ten clear years to deal with Egypt alone, without the embarrassment of anxieties and expenses outside.
A clear account of what Lord Cromer did during this decade of peace has been written once and for all by Lord Milner in his "England in Egypt."*
Let me try to state quite simply and briefly some of his chief reforms.

He found Egypt just emerged from the bankruptcy which had been brought upon her by the "wild-cat" profligacy and extravagance of the Khedive Ismail. The Powers had in- tervened but not to save Egypt. They had deposed Ismail, secured the incomes of the bond-holders, but left the peasantry of Egypt little better off than they were before. The fellaheen were still ground down with a hundred taxes and exactions. They were still denied either justice in their trials or humanity in their punishments. They could be still torn from their homes and enslaved at any moment for either public or private works—just as the Khedive or the Pashas might will.

The first task was to restore freedom. The Corvee, or right of calling out any peasant for work, was abolished, except for sudden levies in time of flood. Conscription was put on a rational basis—the number of soldiers limited, the years of service cut down, and the treatment entirely changed. The spick-and-span Egyptian soldier whom you see in Cairo to day, the smart hero of Atbara and Omdurman, is an entirely different being from the poor weeping wretch who was driven away in chains from his village to die in the Sudan.

The next step was to reduce taxation, and that process is still unfinished. But the severest burdens have been relaxed. The tax on sheep and goats, the tax on all trades and crafts, the tax on fishing—all these and many other smaller but still oppressive burdens have been remitted. The tax on land must be retained as the chief source of revenue in an agricultural country ; but it has been immensely reduced, especially in the poorer provinces. Railway rates have been continually lowered, and every- thing is still being done to cheapen transit and encourage trade.

Lord Cromer has not been content with merely removing hardens. Egypt is the only country in the world where the skill and in- genuity of the State can double or treble the richness of the soil, for Egypt is, in Herodotus' old phrase, the "gift of the Nile." It literally consists of the soil brought down by the Nile, and depends yearly for its crops on the Nile
waters alone. He, therefore, who can entirely subdue the Nile to the service of man can increase, the wealth of Egypt indefinitely.

The Egyptians had often tried their hands at the task, from the times of the old Pharaohs until now. But when we went to Egypt they had never got very far beyond the old "basin" system described by Herodotus, and still pre- vailing in Upper Egypt to day. The Khedive Mehemet had employed a Frenchman to build a dam across the Nile just below Cairo, but Mehemet had never had the skill to use it, and we found it lying idle and useless.

Our first task was to put this dam—the Cairo "barrage"—in order. This was done by Sir Colin Scott Moncrieff, who came from India, and did wonders for Lower Egypt. The barrage was put in order, and it enabled the Government to start a double system of canals all over the Delta so arranged as to introduce the year-round irrigation. In other words, the land is never entirely submerged, but is continually fed by the life giving water, and thus produces throughout the year a continual series of beautiful crops. Ever green, ever fertile, passing without pause or weariness from one rich output to another, this land of Lower Egypt is now one of the richest in the world.

The next step was to extend this great benefit to Upper Egypt, and after many, inquiries Assouan was chosen as the place for a second dam, with a barrage at Assiout. It looked as if it would be impossible to obtain the £3,000,000 required. For Egypt is treated, by the Law of Liquidation as an undischarged bankrupt, and not allowed to borrow any money on its own account. But a way out was found by a private loan, extending over many years, from Sir Ernest Cassel, and the contract was accepted, as all the world knows, by Sir John Aird. The work was finished in 1902, and now a great wall of granite, 150 feet high, and a mile and a half broad, runs from bank to bank of the Nile above Assouan. It is one of the most wonderful works of man in the world, and enables one engineer to regulate the whole flow of the river down to Cairo. Already —in 1903—it has saved Egypt from one famine.

The truest test of prosperity in the East is always population, and if we apply that to Egypt we find that Lord Cromer's policy has produced the most astonishing results. Between 1882 and 1897 the population increased by 43 per cent. It went up from nearly 7,000,000 to nearly 10,000,000, and though the rate of increase has happily moderated a little, it is still going on at a great pace. The devastating agencies have been checked and the fertilising agencies encouraged.
Such is Lord Cromer's role.

If you wish to realise the increased wealth and happiness of Egypt under all these measures, you must ride, or walk, as we did for several months at the beginning of the present year, through the fields and among the villages of Egypt. As you watch the people at their work and listen to their songs and laugh- ter, note their clean clothes and bright faces, their merry children and happy, child-hearted women, you gain an impression of happiness which, alas ! you no longer find on the country- side of old England.

Come with me some bright radiant morning —such a morning as you only get in Egypt in the opening of the year—on the great raised road that runs across the plain from the Nile at Luxor to the distant Arabian hills. As you trot along on your donkey —that white, large-limbed, patient beast of Egypt—you meet a constant succes- sion of peasants going out or coming in from the fields, driving great flocks or herds, carry- ing on their heads great bundles of fodder for the cattle, greeting you cheerfully with an Arabic "Good-morning," sometimes plodding along on foot, often on donkeys or camels. There is no sign of poverty, little begging, except where the tourists have gone by, every mark of that slow, long industry which, in the East, takes the place of our feverish Western activity.

When he goes through the fields or down the river on one of his simple, favorite holi- day trips, Lord Cromer must feel that his long patient labours—the labours of twenty-two continuous years—have not been in vain.

div.head: HISTORY OF A KRUGER WREATH
div.p: In connection with other public bodies in the country, the Zeerust (Transvaal) Town Councillors forwarded, on behalf of the in- habitants of the district, a wreath for the coffin of the late President Kroger. The cost, amounting to £2, was paid out of the town funds, and to this there is an interesting sequel. The Government auditor has called upon the members to refund the money on the ground that the expenditure was "not a lawful disbursement of municipal funds, the matter not being of general public interest." Indignant demand, the members have refused to comply with the auditor's request, and intimated that he may take what action he likes. The councillors are supported in their attitude by the ratepayers, and the ultimate result is awaited with interest.

div.head: Distinguished French Actress
div.p: Mlle Bartet, of the Comedie-Francaise, has been appointed to the rank of a Knight of the Legion of Honour, and is thud the first actress to receive this decoration in special recognition of her talent. Mlle Jeanne-Julia Regnault, dite Bartet, was born in Paris in 1854, and after studying at the Conservatoire under Bo- nier made her debut at the Vaudeville in 1872 as Vivette in "L'Arlesienne." In 1888 she first appeared at the Comedie-Francaise in "Daniel Rochat." The following are a few of the plays in which she has since appeared : "Mme Caverlet," "Francillon," "Denise" "Thermidor," "Dora," and in most of the masterpieces of the repertoire of the,"House of Moleire," as well as in the plays of the drama- tists of to-day, MM. Lavedan, Heryieu, Don- nay, Capus, Brieux, and Curel. Her latest role was in "Le Duel." In addition to Mlle Bartet, the other members of the Comedie-Francaise who belong to the Legion of Honor are ; MM. Mounet-Sully, Coquelin cadet, Leloir, Silvain, de Feraudy, and Le Bargy, actors; M. Jules Claretie, director-general ; and MM. Edouard Noel and Lemaire, readers.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Coton. Samedi et lundi il y a eu de la fer- meté et de la hausse sur les contrats ; les deux jours suivants, nous avors été un peu plus calmes, quoique soutenus ; jeudi la faiblesse a prévalu sur des réalisations en prévision d'un Bnreau favorable à la récolte américaine et finalement aujourd'hui, après avoir commencé la matinée en bonne tendance, le recul constaté en clôture d'hier s'est accentué. Voilà en peu de mots quelles ont été l'allure et la tenue do notre marohé pendant la semaine qui vient de finir. Que pour certaines séanoes l'aotivité ait été plus ou moins grande ou que la spécu lation se soit montrée par moments plus ou moins bien disposée, le résumé de tout cela est que nous finissons en baisse de 1/8 de tallari environ sur Vendredi dernier, ce qui équivaut aux douze ou quatorze points perdus par New- York depuis lors. Nous n'avocs donc fait que snivijB l'Amérique pas à pas, comme du reste c'est le cas depuis quelque temps, et sans le rapport mensuel de Washington qui est venu créer une diversion passagère et faire naître une petite agitation parmi le monde de la Bourse, nous n'aurions, pour cette fois, absolu- ment rien eu d'intéressant à enregistrer, leR faits locaux ayant continué à nous faire défaut d'une façon complète.

Mais si la marche de la vieille récolte a été toute pacifique et uniquement guidée par celle de l'Américain, il n'en a pss été de même pour ce qui regarde l'Août. La persistance de la de- mande pour certains classements en disponible et les prix que l'exportation a payés, la main plutôt forcée que de bonne grâce, ont produit du raffermissement, qui a fini par se traduire par une hausse totale ds 11/16 sur le cours d*' Vendredi dernier.

Dans nos précédentes revues, nous avions bien signalé les besoins en fully good fair et good Mit Afifi qui restaient à couvrir pour quelques filateurs ; nous avions également prévu les gros embarquements qui ont fourni îe premier point d'appui aux haussiers sur la récolte actuelle ; mais, au fond et contraire- ment à oe qui arrive, nous étions persuadés que les vendeurs auraient été les premiers à faire des concessions pour arriver à liqnider l'Août. Nous nous sommes trompés sur ce point et notre excuse est que les ordres d'achat ont été plus urgents qu'on ne l'aurait supposé, qu'il n'y avait qu'un seul détenteur des qua- lités voulues, le groupe qui avait reçu le Mai, et que ce détenteur devait tout naturelle- ment chercher à tirer profit de la moindre cir constance.

Le disponible, qui avait commencé calme, a fini très actif et avec des cours en hanese de 3/8 à 3/4 de tallari, snivant le genre et le classement ; cette amélioration dans les prix ne doit nullement surprendre après ce que non* venons de dire à propos des contrats Août.

Quant aux exportations, elles sont supé Heures à tonte attente et pour le moment le surplus sur l'année dernière est de Bal. J4,000 ce qui laisse le stock à Car tare 11,000 au dessous de celui existant à la même date ev 1904. Les deux différences en question augmen- teront encore davantage la semaine prochaine, les prévisions, comme expéditions, étant encor-- pour des quantités relativement importantes

Liverpool n'a pas été mauvais pour ros cotons : il est vrai qu'en définitive les cours n'ont pas varié mais en somme la d mand est bonne et le marché reste soutenu, fait qu: semble quelque peu extraordinaire avec nr stock s'élevant presque au double de celui d- l'année dernière à pareille époque. Là-bar, comme ici, ce sont encore les Fully good fair et Good Beurrés, pas bien abondants pour sûr, qui sont le plus recherchés. Les bonnes pro- venances Haute-Egypte jouissent aussi d'uDr certaine demande à des prix favorables aux détenteurs.

Le rapport du Bureau d'Agriculture dr Washington donnant la condition de la plante comme étant, de 74 9/10 %, oontre91 6/10 l'année dernière, n'a pas été en général une surprise, tous les pronostics câblés lesjonn précédents ayant été entre 72 et 77 ; mal ce qui n'a pas plu à beaucoup de nos spé culateurs, c'est la baisse qui a suivi sa publication. Certes, en apparence, il y a con tradiotion entre les deux faits, ffiais doito) s'en étonner si Ion pense que tous somme à 6 ponce environ-, que ce prjx, ^ jn: même, escompte beaucoup de choses et q depuis que nons pommes à ce niveau tou les renseignements de Manchester ne fout que répéter que les acheteurs de mannfsr. tares *0 dérobent 1 Et puis, justifié ou nen oe monvement à la baisse, s'il De s'imj o-ai' point, était voulu et l'onsnimité avec la quelle les gros joueurs américains ont cberoLé les dendm Jour* qui ont précédé l'apparition

du dit rapport, à préparer l'opinion publi- que, nous le prouve amplement. Cela ne les empêchera point, le jour où ils seront rentrés dans l'article, après avoir oréé le déconvert qu'il lenr fiant, de reoommenoer une manœu- vre dans le sens contraire, surtout si les conditions olimatériques viennent leur fournir un prétexte plausible.
En attendant, les personnes compétentes disent que, sauf par la sécheresse, il n'y a jamais eu de récolte réellement atteinte en Amérique et cette année o'est de l'excès de pluies que l'on se plaint.
Chez nous, la récolte va admirablement bien et le résnmé de la Produoe Association pour le mois de Juillet, que nous reproduisons plus loin, en est ane preuve éloquente.

Graines de coton : Mercredi a enregistré le maximum de la baisse produite par la crainte des filières, mais dès qu'on s sn que les 254,000 ardebs passés entre agences ont tons été arrê- tés, une reprise marquée s'est produite et l'Août est remonté jusqu'à P.T. 57 j, soit P.T. 1^ de hausse. Malheureusement, œtte amélio- ration ne se maintient pas facilement, car do nonvean nous sommes aux alentours de 57, ce qni ferait supposer qu'une partie de l'Août arrêté est pour compte de petits faiseurs qui ne font qne chercher l'occasion de sortir. Hall, qai s'était raffermi, est de nouveau plus oalme, mais, en fia de compte, il a acheté beaucoup ces temps derniers et les perspectives sont tou- jours bonnes pour la consommation de la graine de coton. Ce qui nons a fait un peu concurrence depuis un mois, o'est Bombay qui a aussi vendu des quantités assez rondes pour embarquement Août, Septembre et Ootobre.
Les expéditions de la semaine prochaine feront sensiblement baisser notre stock.
La nouvelle récolta est toujours inactive, mais comme il n'y a pas de pression de la part des veadeurs, elle se maintient très ferme. A Hall aussi, les coure restent à £6 plutôt acheteurs.

Feves. Il n'y a absolument rien à dire sur cet article, car au fond il ne s'y tait rien et les cours affichés ne sont que des prix imaginaires. En disponible, il n'y a qne la consommation locale et celle de l'intérieur qui opèrent. Alexandrie, 4 Août 1905.
P.S.—Manchester câble que les filateurs du Lancashire ont accepté l'augmentation de 5 % sur les salaires demandée par les ouvriers. Le danger d'uDe grève à partir du 18 contant est donc éoarté.

Les Cotonniers en ont bien profité et, dans les Provinces les plus importantes, ont regagr é le retard précédemment signalé ; leur aspect est en général pins vigourenx et prospère que l'année passée, à cette époque.

L eau a été suffisante, bien que plusieurs cultivateurs eussent voulu des arrosages pins généreux et plus en rapport aux besoins de juillet qui, avant la crue du Nil, est le mois le plus exigeant de l'année.

On note que les vers ont été moins nom- breux qu'en 1904 ; la forte chaleur et les mesures adoptées par le Gouvernement ont été efficaces ; — ces insectes sont d'aillenrs en pleine décroissance et ont pn être extirpés, jufqu'à présent sans qu'ils occasionnent des dégâts.
Les informations de la Haute-Egypte conri- nueut à être favorables.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
div.p: Kearsley and Cunninqham's Weekly Report.
Liverpool, 27th July.
Only a moderate business has been done in Egyptian Cotton this week, and the quotation of Fully Good Fair Brown is exceptionally raised 1/16 per lb.
In Futures a fair business has been done, and the following are the latest values :— July 7.50 Sep. 7.42 Nov. 7.34 Ang. 7.46 Oct. 7.38 Dec. 7.31 Jan. 7.28

American Futures. The Market this week has been very a tive, with frequent fluctua- tions ; an opening decline of 7 points was followed by an upward movement of from 23 @ 25 points, which culminated yesterday afternoon in anticipation of a revised acreage report gives the decrease in acreage as 14.9 against the estimate of 11.4 on the 3rd June last. This estimate, which is certainly "Bullish"

in character, was the occasion for the Bull clique in New York to liquidate the remainder of their interest and caused a sharp décliné in that market which has been reflected here to- day. Closing prices are 1 @ 3 points below those of last Thursday. In such ucsettled market conditions it is impossible to form any decided opinion, but in view of the Bureau report to be issued this day week, the 3rd proximo, we do not anticipate any very decided movement but rather frequent and probably sharp fluctuations.

The following are the latest quotations :— July 5.79 Oct./Nov. 5.81 Feb./Mar. 5.84 July/Aug. 5.79 Nov./Dec. 5.82 Mar./Apl. 5.85 Aug./Sep. 5.79 Dec./Jan. 5.83 Apr./May 5.86 Sep./Oct 5.80 Jan./Feb. 5.84.
