div.head: OUR LONDON LETTER.
div.p: London, July 28.

The King left Victoria Station by special train on Wednesday morning for Chatham, where he unveiled the Royal Engineers' war memorial, and opened the new naval hospital. His Majesty arrived at noon at Rochester Banks Station, where the Mayors and Town Clerks of Rochester, Chatham and Gillingham were presented. Through gaily-decorated streets the Royal party drove to Chatham. After the first ceremony, lunch was served at the Royal Engineers' mess.

To the address of welcome presented on behalf of the Corporation of Chatham the King replied as follows : "I thank you for your loyal address, and I am much gratified by the hearty welcome with which the town of Chatham again received me. It is my sincere wish that con- stant progress and the full measure of prosperity may be granted to your town, which has such close relations with my naval and military services, and I am glad that one of the purpo- ses of my present visit is the opening of a new and fine hospital for the relief and benefit of the men belonging to my Navy. I cordially associate myself with you in hoping that the memorial which is to-day unveiled may be treasured in your midst as a record of the loyal devotion and heroism of officers and men of the Royal Engineers who consummated their services to their country by dying in her cause." Both the King and the Duke of Connaught, who accompanied him, wore the undress uni- form of a field marshal. The King was at- tended by Major Holford and Colonel David- son, and General Sir Neville Lyttelton also travelled. The Home Secretary had been present at Victoria to see the King off.

The memorial is placed immediately oppo- site the Crimean Memorial Arch, being be- tween the inner parade of Brompton Barracks and the forecourt of the Royal Engineers' Institute. A principal feature of the structure is a series of panels in high relief depicting the various works effected by sappers in war time. Two other panels representing Paardeberg and Wagon Hill, where the Engineers particularly distinguished themselves, are required to com- plete the series. All the pictures have an historical value, in as much as they are based upon photographs of actual incidents and scenes. The keystones of the arch are figures of Victory, and the broad piers at the abut- ments have Istrian marble tablets, on which are recorded in leaded letters the names of the officers, warrant officers, non-commissioned officers, and men—some 420 in all—of the Regular, Militia, and Volunteer Engineers who lost their lives in the South African war.

Wednesday was a great day for Wimbledon, for at noon it ceased to be an ordinary urban district and became a full fledged borough. The event was celebrated with great rejoicings. The baby borough gave itself over to treating the occasion in no half-hearted manner. The Charter Mayor, Mr. Hamshaw, accompanied by the Charter Town Clerk, Mr. Butterworth, arrived at the Home Office shortly after 10 a.m, where they received the charter, which was waiting for them. They drove in a pair- horse carriage. Next they proceeded to the west side of Westminster Bridge in order to meet the Lord Mayor and one of the Sheriffs of London. A few minutes before Big Ben sounded the half-hour the City state coaches were seen coming at a trot down the Embank- ment, escorted by two mounted policemen.

When they arrived at Boadicea's statue the Charter Mayor and the Town Clerk of Wim- bledon left their carriage, and introduced themselves first to Alderman Sir John Pound and Lady Pound, the Lord Mayor and the Lady Mayoress, who were in the second car- riage, and then to the Sheriff, Sir George Woodman, who was accompanied by Lady Woodman. As the half-hour struck the pro- cession drove across the bridge for Wimbledon.

On their return at noon the charter proces- sion was received with befitting honors. On arriving at the borough boundary the proces- sion was met by forty-seven carriages, mostly occupied by distinguished guests, and the town clerk read portions of the charter, after which a military band played "God Save the King." The procession then moved to the town-hall, where the charter was read in full and a short religious service held. A luncheon followed, at which the Lord Mayor presided. In the evening the school children and the old people were entertained, and there was a military tattoo, a torch-light procession, and a bonfire on the common.

Autre temps, autres maeurs, and this genera- tion has surely reached the lowest depths of Parliamentary ill manners. Hardly a day can pass without some one being excessively rude and offensive to somebody else in the House of Commons. The poison of discourtesy has infected most persons and all parties. Mr. Churchill's offensive rancour, directed against the Prime Minister, who sets the best example to others less courteous than himself, is well known, and "C.B." has lately tried the in- dulgence accorded to an offensively stupid, if naturally amiable, gentleman very far. But it is only just to acknowledge that the conduct of those who mimicked Mr. Churchill's stam- mer was quite as bad and inexcusable as that of their opponents. There are still gentlemen in the House. But the air of Westminster seems to nullify the effects of good breeding and education. There is no chance of Parlia- ment's regaining its hold on public esteem until it mends its manners.

It is now some four months since the Com- mission of Inquiry into the alleged atrocities in the Congo returned to Belgium, and their report has not yet been issued. But there has just been published what might be described as a bowdlerised summary of the evidence taken, and this, in all conscience, is convincing enough. The book has been compiled by the Congo Reform Association, of which Lord Beauchamp is president, and which has a most distinguished committee of peers and members of Parliament. It confines itself entirely to the testimony given before the Commission, without a word of comment. And the con- clusion to be drawn from reading its pages is that the atrocities and outrages which such persistent attempts have been made to deny or discredit were considerably understated, and that the terrible reality transcends the pictures painted from transitory glimpses of incidents which had hitherto leaked out. What we read in this book is sufficiently revolting. But there are worse things that it omits: They are un- printable. It is no longer possible for the charges against the Congo Administration to be denied or palliated. The next move must be towards punishment and—more important still—reform.

The National Trust has an opportunity of acquiring for purposes of preservation the beautiful Tudor mansion known as Barrington Court, situated about four miles from Ilmins- ter. Barrington Court is well-known among lovers of good architecture as one of the finest houses in Somerset. It dates from the middle of the 16th century. As a house in which the Duke of Monmouth stayed during his tour in the West in 1680, it forms a connecting link with some of the more stirring events of English history.

The house is about to rasa into the hands of one who is willing to sell it, with 220 acres of land, to the National Trust for £10,500. Towards the purchase price and necessary repairs (£11,500) an anonymous donor has promised £10,000 on certain terms. Owing to this offer it will not be necessary to ask the general public to subscribe more than the balance of £1,500. For this sum the Council, therefore, appeals.

Since the motor took possession of the land the public have begun to realise how impor- tant is the question of roads, their mainte- nance and their construction. And now we see a definite result of this awakening in the intro- duction of a Highways Bill, which seeks to create a central department charged with the control of old roads and the construction on a definite plan of new ones. It is premature to canvass the precise merits of the whole pro- posal, which includes a provision to classify certain roads as "national roads," but its initiation must lead to a quickening of interest that will not be amiss. Perhaps the first highway problem awaiting solution is that of dust, which has become a nuisance that must be checked in the interests both of pedestrians, householders, and motorists. It is time, too, that wider and better roads were made that should bring us up to the level of France in this matter, and it is extremely important that the construction of new suburban thorough- fares should be intelligent and farsighted. The objects of the new Bill are really less surpris- ing than its tardy introduction.

We have made very considerable progress in our prison system, both as regards principle and practice, daring the past century or so. But in some matters the law and its represen- tatives continue most egregiously asinine, to put it at its mildest. That a Chinese prisoner, incarcerated for this heinous crime of smuggling tobacco, should have had his pigtail cut off by the prison barber is an illustration of stupidity and brutality which is not to be excused by any plea of adherence to regulations or routine. In another case, which is at present attracting a good deal of attention—that of the Dartmoor prisoners whose portraits have appeared on picture postcards—it would appear to be ra- ther the lack of proper regulations which has caused a lapse no less discreditable to the authorities concerned. Each of these cases points to a lack of appreciation of the fact that the value of prison discipline lies not in its punitive, but in its reformatory effect. The object should be torestore, not further to impair, the prisoner's self-respect.

An interesting suggestion has been put for- ward in some quarters as to the possibility of feeding underfed London school children from the cookery centres in the metropolis. Probably no one can speak with greater expert knowledge on the subject than the Superin- tendent of the National School of Cookery. Her opinion can be summed up in one sentence. "I do not think it is possible under the exist- ing conditions," she said to a press repre- sentative. "Enough time is not allowed for the teaching of school, children pupils at present. If they had to prepare meals for the underfed scholars their opportunities for learning would be seriously hindered. A child, who may come either from a non-provided school or a London County school attends the class here, according to the existing regulations, for two hours once a week during the school year. The girl thus gets forty hours' tuition, half of which is spent in listening to lectures.

"I have, however, during the last week, re- ceived some information from an Australian lady as to a scheme by which cheap meals are produced by school children at the cookery centres in that country. There the children attend the class for a whole day once a week for a period of six months. With such a sys- tem of attendance it is possible to import a thoroughly useful knowledge of the subject. Furthermore, much of their time is not taken up by listening to lectures. With the limited time at their disposal practice is far more valuable than precept. The meals which the girls produce are sold to the general public at sixpence a head in a dining-room attached to the cookery school. The girls lay the tables, serve the dinners, and perform the clearing away and washing-up. They thus gain a valuable additional training in these duties."

In reply to a question as to how far such a system might be adopted here, the super- intendent said she thought it showed what was possible. "Of course," she continued, "you have out in Australia a new country untram- melled by traditions and red tape. But if the school-children there can produce dinners of three or four courses, which are sold at six- pence, and yet bring in sufficient revenue as they do, to make the cookery centres com- mercially self-supporting, I think it demon- strates what might be done for the underfed scholars here. A school child does not need a four-course dinner. I should be inclined to make the children pay a penny or some small sum for their meals to prevent any tendency to pauperise the parents."

div.head: THE BOREDOM OF THE SHAH.
div.p: The King of Kings is bored, and wrinkles mar the saffron-coloured smoothness of the forehead of Samaid Khan, the Shah-in-Shah's Ambassador.
"To-day the Light of my Heart shall smile ; the Hope of his Servant's Life shall indeed be glad, for there is much to interest him."
"Speak ! is the Sun of Suns' brief order, and it is uttered through an unstifled yawn.
"To-day, greatest of Kings," says Samaid Khan again—"to day-------"
'Oh, cut the cackle, and get to the hortheth," murmurs the Lion with the Flaming Sword, who—in a Persian translation by one Omar Bohn -has studied the works of the immortal Charles.

"What am I going to see to-day ? Speak, and speak wisely, or, by the Living Hair of Shagpat (he has apparently read Meredith as well),thou shalt be locked into a room where fifty gramophones are croaking Viens Pou- poule !"

Samaid did his best. He took his master to the Louvre, to the Bois, to the Jardin des Plantes, and to the Musee Grevin. He took him to the Eiffel Tower, the Comedie Fran- caise, the Morgue, and other places of amuse- ment. He showed him motor-cars, airships, a motor train, the Moulin Rouge, and the Post Office, and still Muzaffer ed Din remained desperately bored. He feasted him, and sat him on a throne of gold, the little princes near him upon thronelets cut from crystal, houris from the Grand Opera danced before Muzaffer, and the King yawned them wearily away ; he brought M. Henri Brisson to talk to him, and the Shah remained glum. Nor did his long moustache move when M. Henri Rochefort offered him three Louvre pictures and the helm of Saitaphernes.
In despair at their master's melancholy, his faithful servants carried him on to the balcony of his hotel, which overlooks the Champs Elysees, and Samaid Khan telephoned for Dr. Schneider.
But as Samaid called "Alloh ! Alloh !" and made other remarks into the instrument, another ran to him with the glad news : "The master smiles." Two old ladies were trying to cross the Champs Elysees.

div.head: FRENCH FLEET'S VISIT
div.p: As already announced by telegraph, on the occasion of the visit of the French Fleet to Portsmouth the officers will be entertained to luncheon by the House of Commons in West- minster Hall. It is proposed that the enter- tainment should take place on Saturday, August 12. The suggestion was brought under the notice of members by the chief Government Whip, Sir A. Acland-Hood, and the chief Opposition Whip, Mr. H. Gladstone, who together signed a circular on the subject issued to members of the House.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6.
